job_title: Scheduling Coordinator I in New York, NY
pros:
- You can end up on a good team with great coworkers who will make the job better
- Depending on management you may enjoy your time there
- $21 an hour for 37.5 hours a week
cons:
- Overall feeling of disorganization due to constant changes in staffing
- High volume calls with often short staff (especially on Fridays with my team, leaving 3-4 people answering calls)
- Automatic answering machine makes you feel like a robot
- Depressing environment (dark lighting, cubicles, backroom vibe)
- Strict on petty rules 
- Working here made me question what I was doing with my life, made me depressed, never wanted to go into work, made my skin break out 
- Long boring trainings in the beginning
- Lots of confusion all around
- Need to memorize a lot of information (office staff, provider schedules, who takes what insurance, what days they are in the office, what other offices they are in, who their nurses are, etc.)
- Strict on dressing professionally even though it's just a call center
- Irate patients a lot of the time (they are tired of being given the run around, having to wait, or playing phone tag. Often putting their frustrations on you)
- Having to be the middle man between patients who want to speak with someone at the actual office
- Workers are always complaining about callers or the job which adds to the depressing vibe
- Strict on call outs and PTO, feels like you have no freedom
- Micromanagement on metrics, meetings on how your phone calls are going, lots of clashing or changing of breaks/lunch
- Not enough space for everyone who has lunch to eat on the floor 
- When leaving after a long day there's always a line to wait for the elevator due to so many people leaving at once

job_title: IT Manager in New York, NY

cons: You could work 24 hours, seven days a week and you will still be underwater with workload. Expectations are not set, little to no real time feedback, setting you up for a negative performance review that comes as a surprise. You are not recognized for pouring all your energy into doing a good job, you are only reprimanded for the small percentage of things that didn’t go well despite numerous challenges outside of your control. As if it’s your fault for executive leadership not setting the department up for success by creating unsustainable working conditions. Leadership is detached from the reality of the what their people need to do in order to do their jobs well.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of PTO days
Colleagues are great for the most part
cons:
Senior leaders are clueless to the needs of employees

Low pay and high turnover

Raises given only every other year at 3% or less.  Can't keep up with inflation.  

Overworked, underpaid.  They award good employees with more work, leading to burnout.  

HR is very bureaucractic and never responds to emails. Good luck trying to get an answer if your paycheck has an error or you are missing a paycheck.  You call their number and they direct you to email them, which you then receive an automated message with no actual human response.  Has been a nightmare trying to get answers from HR.  Have never experienced this with previous employers. 

If you receive an outside offer, Mount Sinai would make promises of raises and promotions as an counteroffer but then don't follow through in a timely manner, resulting in opportunity costs.  Have had two colleagues experience this - their promotion and raise took more than a year to materialize and they regret not taking the outside offer.

pros:
1. The doctors are not insane and are good to work with.
2. You can gain a lot of experience which will open doors in other places.
3. It is a union position... if the interests anyone.
4. All the administrative staff are a great team to work with.
cons:
1. Management. (they don't listen to the employees) 
2. The pay will only increase as the union will allow.
3. No title changes, so no room for advancement or promotions
4. Administrative team will have more tasks added on as management sees fit. There is no cap. Admins do it all and are responsible for all. Which can become overwhelming sometimes. 
5. There is no definitive set of tasks and standards for employees. When asked you will not get the posting which entails what your functions are. 
6. Rumors that if you get on the bad side of certain members of management you will be black balled or placed on a do not rehire list. So people are afraid of retaliation 
7. Minimal things are made into mountains by certain members of management and some decisions DO NOT MAKE SENSE with patient flow or clinic flow. 
8. You cover multiple providers plus your own all the time. There aren't enough administrative assistants to handle the amount of doctors.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great colleagues
Flexible
Opportunities for advancement
Good benefits

This varies depending on the department you are in. I am very fortunate to find a great department with good teammates and a supportive boss. COVID has been challenging. There were layoffs and early retirements, resulting in staff taking on extra workload. Despite that, I feel supported by my supervisor and my fellow teammates. We developed ways to streamline operations and we are actively trying to hire new people. I feel recognized for my efforts and there are rewards/promotions available based on promotion. I can't say this is the case for all teams or departments. After all, it can vary with the manager! But I feel motivated and happy with my job.
cons:
Senior management can be a bit out-of-touch
Merit raises are not annual -- can be every other year
Bureucratic

One of the frustrating things about Mount Sinai is how bureaucratic the HR Department and Senior Leadership is. When you want to promote or give raises to your direct reports, you have to go through several approval processes with Position Control. In order to save money, HR has delayed processing new position requests. This can lead to frustration with current staff members, resulting in attrition.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in New York, NY
pros: Pay is good and benefits are great.
cons: The Mount Sinai Hospital system has a very inflated sense of importance and reputation (notice their aggressive branding all over NYC) and they have a culture of working their staff to the bone and expecting you to be grateful for being a part of it all. In my program our workload was regularly increased, everyone on the front lines worked overtime without pay, and if we stood up for ourselves we were told explicitly that we are replaceable.  Management is unsupportive, if present at all, and really unprofessional and petty (and skews white and male, in my experience).  They seem to only care about the bottom line - money  - and not about patient care - that's your problem!  I know social workers, nurses, and supervisors at several programs and everyone hates their job but stays for the pay/benefits. There are numerous excellent workers at these hospitals, but they all get burnt out in the toxic environment and stop caring.  I wouldn't come here if my arm fell off.

pros:
Decent Benefits provided through NYSNA union, insurance coverage with low copay, can accrue up to 5 weeks vacation, competitive salary, 403b access (no match),
Very diverse patient population and staff- different ethnicities, class, religion etc
cons: If you look on their site you will see there are MANY openings, all the time which reflects the fact that we are frequently short on staff and people who cannot keep up with the pace or stress will leave. We were on the news because some nurses were forced to wear trash bags because there was no PPE available. We are often short of supplies. In addition some manager use micro-managing strategies instead of trying to motivate. Overall the quality of life for people who work here is poor and you can hear the defeat in many conversations with staff. Many stay just because of the benefits and want to retire quickly. Which makes it hard to make significant changes because tbh there are people that are not team players but who are not going anywhere.

job_title: Care Management Social Worker in New York, NY
pros: You definitely learn how to manage high case loads, work with an interdisciplinary team. The time off is 31 pto and after 4 years you get 34 days. They offer opportunities for ceu often, and grand rounds. If you have the employee choice insurance you can have medical tests and see almost any msh provider and have 0 copay. There are some professional days you get and tuition reimbursement. You get to learn about the hospital system and possibly depending what sw dept you are in learn many different medical conditions
cons: Great out of grad school in terms of pay and learning but after a few years your pay does not go up very Much. They make you write a paper or get published etc later on to get a small increase to your salary and you can only do this about 4-5 times. If you get your clinical license there is no raise unless you become a supervisor or switch to another department. If you transfer to another role as sw in the hospital no matter how hard the new role is there is no raise. You do see that there are less minority sw working in certain areas of the hospital.

Mount Sinai needs to step it up and hire better and more capable and supportive management. I did not look forward to or enjoy working in such a toxic environment. At the end of the day you are left feeling drained and unappreciated. Management demands such a high volume and unreasonable amount of work that is impossible for one recruiter to accomplish and we are not compensated for overtime as well. The way I see it, management bullies, plays favoritism, and loves to point blame on innocent employees. There's no wonder that so many employees in the talent acquisition department of Mount Sinai are leaving because there is no return for the amount of work being put in for this company. And again, did I already mention that management is horrible?

review_title: IT Organization that doesn't like change
job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
1. 8% of your salary goes to a 403b for free
2. Won't get fired for doing bare minimum work
3. Good amount of PTO days
4. Extremely flexible if you have kids
5. Lots of exciting projects
cons:
Speaking solely for the Epic IT department.
1. Huge gap between analysts across the teams. I would say 90% of them do the bare minimum of their responsibilities while 10% are trying their best to keep the IT department afloat. Managers know this and continue to burn out their high performers. Some people even consider this their "second job" since they are mostly responding emails/making phone calls for their side hustle. 
2. No clear vision for the future of Epic IT. This is why the IT content is so horribly built. They keep piecemealing modules slowly which leads to fragmented workflows that cause patient safety concerns. Big Bang Go-Live? Don’t even mention that to the leadership here, they don’t believe in doing things that make sense. 
3. Project Management office is a joke. Since they aren't invested in the success of a project, they don't contribute a lot. Often times, you will get pinged from them after a meeting to explain what was discussed and basically write meeting minutes for them. These people are essentially making 150k just to book meetings.
4. Mount Sinai doesn't believe in raises. You either get promoted or stay with the same salary for the rest of your time there. I have spoken with other analysts at other NYC hospitals and they all have some sort of yearly raise system. If you do get promoted, the % increase is flat out repulsive and disrespectful. You will frequently find that external hires make significantly more than the folks who have stayed with the organization. 
5. IT leadership will not defend you against the wrath of delusional operational stakeholders. They will drive a bus over your body and reverse to kiss the behinds of arrogant misguided project sponsors. The ones that scream the loudest, often get what they want. Your priorities will shift constantly day to day. This might be true for a lot of organizations but you’d be surprised how bad it is here. 
6. The environment is almost like a cult. Those who speak up against bad decisions / impossible timelines are viewed as troublemakers. They use key phrases like “solution oriented” or “positive attitude” to mask the insanity that is happening. Think Theranos or Fyre Festival level of delusion. Someone on the team best described projects like a watermelon. People keep reporting Green to upper leadership but realistically it’s Red. There is no accountability horizontally or vertically until there is a need for a scapegoat and it’s you.
7. Just like how Mount Sinai doesn’t believe in investing in their employees, they don’t invest in their technology either. You’re left with using archaic laptops with frequent Citrix outages. Having worked at multiple hospitals prior to Mount Sinai, Epic is absurdly slow here.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: Top 20 medical research institution with all the trimmings.  Some of the best scientists in the world, depending on the department.  Immunology, neuroscience, and virology are especially strong.  Good housing options for scientific staff, despite the low pay that is common in science jobs.  Good research opportunities for medical staff.
cons: Research scientists are often at odds with or ignored by medical center-focused employees.  Often there is tension over research vs. clinical space dedication.  Management is too focused on creating headlines rather than improving quality of life for employees.  Facilities are uneven and it's a crapshoot whether you get a shiny new lab or a really awful, old one.  Employee quality of life also varies a LOT depending on department.  Often, restrictions will come down onto research staff that are required for medical staff and make no sense for research facilities.  This includes HIPAA compliance for mobile email.  NOT necessary for a basic scientist.  Likewise, numerous CYA measures can add hassles to an already difficult business.  Support staff (shipping, engineering, administrative) are often incompetent, slow to respond to email, or simply unavailable during regular business hours, making basic tasks nearly impossible.

review_title: Great Place to work and begin your career
job_title: Social Worker in New York, NY
pros:
Please note that this review is coming from an outpatient clinic position. 

I was hired right after graduating from my MSW program. It was a great way to begin my career. On boarding took almost a month. Training and an extensive orientation was provided, which was really nice. There are opportunities to shadow other senior social workers as well before being given a caseload. 

CEUs are offered and encouraged to attend. Supervisors are available for supervision, if not, my peers were the best support . I was able to obtain all hours required for LCSW application very quickly. The Social Work Department at the main campus offers great benefits and the highest PTO I have ever been offered, and it increases more after 4 years of employment! (more than 25 days) - note that other MSH sites have different benefits and PTO packages. Perhaps because I was in an outpatient setting, my Social Work Department and supervisors were very supportive of any additional extra curricular activities and post education courses I was interested in.
cons: It is a huge hospital network, can burn out and probably will after being 6+months in. Sometimes providers can look down at Social Workers and not fully understand our work. I personally worked for a medicaid funded program and it was constantly changing our forms, documentation, eligibility to work with clients, etc. - need a lot of flexibility

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: It differs greatly by department -- some are excellent and some are not to be recommended. In my department , which is focused on cancer research, there is a great deal of academic freedom. Any area of research I would like to pursue is open to me, as long as I can secure the funding and be productive. I have found the people to be highly collegial, and the environment is very research-oriented, so resources are generally good. The grants office does a good job of assisting with the completion and submission of grants, and the IRB is very easy to work with and relatively quick. The institution, which was struggling financially in the early 2000s, is now strong and appears to be heading in a very positive direction. Thus, the outlook is very good.
cons: PhDs are not as highly respected as MDs, and there are relatively few awards open to us. That can make it difficult to add important honors and awards to our CVs. The quality of the departments varies (however, that is likely to be the case at many large institutions). Some of the red tape is terrible. Accounts Payable is particularly bad, and getting contractors paid can be a hellish and time-consuming experience.

job_title: Labor Relations Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Outside of HR, clinical colleagues are awesome

HR offices on E98 are completely atrocious. They’re matchbox size and filthy.
Labor Relations management is racist, unethical and manage with bias and favoritism. Inappropriate relations with employees is the norm with this team, and they do not seek to have a harmonious work relationship with the union.
They look down on minorities, are not FOR the people, and gossip and taint the reputation of the hard working NYSNA, 32BJ and 1199 employees that work hard for little pay. The Labor officers are unfair and 99% of the time side with management. The HR team will overwork and underpay you, while discouraging career progression. They are unsupportive of real talent and stifle and suppress any employee who shows growth potential.
If Maksoud only knew what went on in the Labor Relations office; what’s said, what’s done and how employees are being treated, her jaw would hang for days. Having worked on this team for years, and having first hand seen and heard all of the nasty politics, I'd advise you to STAY AWAY FROM THIS TEAM, or learn the hard way! Labor Relations management may seem cool during the interview, but that office is full of skeletons and the women of that office all engage in unheard things I cannot mention here. Oh and like pay, health benefits are poor.

job_title: in Secaucus, NJ
pros:
Workers, (non-management), are competent and professional even under this harsh work environment.

There is a decent amount of vacation time.
cons:
The Data Center itself is in poor shape.  The carpeting and bathrooms are filthy. Also, as often as not, the HVAC leaves you either too cold or too hot.  

As a rule, management demeans and shows contempt for the staff.

Training to acquire new skills is non-existent.

There is no prioritization.  Everything is urgent and needs to be done right away regardless of the amount of "urgent" things you're already working on.

You can pretty much forget raises and promotions unless you kiss up to the right people.  Of course if you do that you risk being the one they'll throw under the bus when there's a problem.

Your personal life is inconsequential to management.  As far as they're concerned you are expected to live and breathe work.

Turnover is sky high and management's response is to threaten people if they talk about it. In fact this can be said to be a standard response from management to any issue that reflects poorly on top leadership.

All things must be done with an eye towards covering yourself since finger pointing in the face of a problem outweighs solving the issue as far as management is concerned.

Management is extremely top-heavy and only about 1/4 know what they're doing with the rest simply look for someone to blame and fire when things go wrong.

review_title: Don't let bad professors continue to destroy career paths of trainees
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
-the location of Mount Sinai is top-notch, ability to work and live in Manhattan
-the school has made an effort to hire some very smart & talented people (but doesn't seem to be able to handle them when they are on the inside)
cons:
-pay is low for Manhattan
-it seems getting R01 is the only metric being evaluated for how successful a professor is... many toxic professors running labs that are destroying careers of trainees
-the school knows about destructive professors but nothing is done.  If a lab has a 95% attrition rate in 3-4 years, and not one of those people are going on to successful positions, it means it's a problem with the professor & not the trainees.  
-the environment is inbred and nepotistic - only if you come from a certain lab's lineage will you be given the tools and resources to be successful
-extremely bureaucratic - if you have a problem with something, good luck trying to GUESS who's job it is to help you sort through it, because you get a lot of responses "that's not my job, I don't know who you can speak to" (meanwhile they do know, but just don't want to tell you)
-toxic environment - many issues in many departments

review_title: Good place to be a post-doc
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
Great research environment and exciting location in Manhattan. There are a wealth of scientific resources at Mount Sinai and the post-doc community is very strong there. Further, there are so many other research institutions in the city that you feel constantly surrounded by the latest developments in biology and medicine.

There are solid benefits (although health insurance in general has been getting worse for everybody). There is discounted housing for post-docs available close to the hospital and in the Upper East Side which is a major plus so that you don't have to live in the Bronx or Queens and commute in. The housing is available for up to three years.
cons: The salary range is still low for living in Manhattan. As a postdoc, expect "subsidized housing" to cost at least 1400 a month for a shoebox and 1700 a month for a breathable studio. Prices are generally more for larger apartments and those are reserved for families or people who agree to share apartments. Accept that you won't be saving much money during this chapter in your life.

review_title: Ok if you don't have a personal life and don't mind the back stabbing.
job_title: Corporate Job in New York, NY
pros: 1.  Large organization that allows mobility for skilled employees.  2.  Hospitals are located in nice areas in Manhattan (not that you'll enjoy it much since you'll be working all the time).  3.  Direct care staff is dedicated to quality service to the patients. 4.  Good benefits and time off.  5. Competitive salaries.  6. There are one or two wonderful people that work there.
cons: 1.  Large and impersonal organization requires you to spend lots of time making sure you cover your rear as you do your job. 2.  Dedication to patients is not seen in the administrative offices of the organization.   3.  You have to know the right people to get ahead and the same right people will stab you in the back if they deem it necessary.  4. Executive leadership is out of touch with realities of the day to day operations.  They just come up with crazy ideas that get dropped when the next crazy idea comes along.  Few major projects come to fruition. 5. You are expected to sacrifice your personal life for the job.

review_title: Seems like a great place to work.  Until you work there.
job_title: Physician Associate in New York, NY
pros: It's a fairly famous hospital that has a good reputation for excellence in medical care.  The patient population they treat is great.  Very nice people who deserve and appreciate great care.  There is a good mix of poor and indigent patients accompanied with those that are VPs and CEOs of major companies.
cons: The place is huge!  There is so much waste and redundancy that it is unbelievable.   A lot of the management was chosen due to their popularity rather than their ability to lead.  There is a lot of back room negotiations and sometimes things make absolutely no sense.  When a management position becomes available it seems like it is given to the person that will put up the least resistance and simply say 'yes' to what the administrators want to do.  There is no outlet for a regular employee to give someone an idea and get the proper recognition.

review_title: Stay away from this place. They will rescind their offer two weeks before you start your job
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
Located in Manhattan, NY
Easy recruiting process
cons:
If you hate NYC, it is not the place to work certainly.
But most important thing is they treat their postdoctoral fellows like a piece of nobody. They pay them minimal wages and the administrative staffs are very mean. The administrative staff has the power over the PI (who is oversea on vacation) to rescind the offer two weeks before their job start  and even persuade PI not to sponsor visa when PI has already promised it to the candidate. While all this should happen much sooner if administrative staff has any concerns before they issued the offer letter to the Candidate for the PI. It felt like administrative staffs are actually the ones who runs the place not the PI. They don't care if the offer letter is a legal binding contract indeed and left all the mess for candidate to clean up such as past job opportunities after accepting their offer, paid housing lease,  terminated current housing lease and moving arrangement deposit and etc. As the matter of fact, none of the postdoctors I contacted in this hospital ever worked longer than 2 years raised a big red flag to me.

job_title: Nurse Care Manager in Astoria, NY
pros: bear the name of Mount Sinai Health System.
cons: working in Mount Sinai Queens is like you are detached from what mount sinai health system envision-. cheap, impossible processes, outdated system, outdated processes, outdated mentality, discrimination, politics, micromanaging to the highest level, leadership not open to updates, understaffing issue, and all they want is money. benefits through union which is 1199, but very weak. also, you are not entitled to vacation within your first 6 months, then you will accrue it from 6th to 12th month and it's only 2 weeks. Leadership is allergic to the union policy, still do their decision without approval of the union, and yet union cant say nor do anything about it. leaders of each department argue and fights each other because of demands and not willing to compromise for the sake of the organization. leaders use their subordinates to actually communicate with the leaders to address issues, and dont talk to each other. leaders seems to be detached to one another. some people in the leadership are also incompetent.

job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: The prestige of working for Mount Sinai in NYC, accessible location. Grasping at straws here, there aren't many pros.
cons:
Not much good can be said about the Department of Psychiatry at Mount Sinai West (formerly St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital). Ever since Mount Sinai acquired it out and installed their own administration, staff, and policies -- this new philosophy of prioritizing profits has conflicted with the values of longtime staff. Bottom line: they do not care about you, no matter who you are or how long you've been there.

Per-diem staff are stonewalled from ever getting a full time position, despite the NYSNA contract agreements. Instead, you're given the runaround. You are replaceable, and they're probably counting the days until you quit or retire so they can bring their own colleagues on board. 

Management within the Department of Psychiatry is an absolute mess. Zero communication across all levels. The number one takeaway from this must be: management  = crazier than the patients. They are consistently the least experienced staff on the floor, yet they are tasked with managing the crisis. You'll spend an unreasonable amount of time cleaning up their mess, de-escalating patients they inexplicably manage to rile up.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros:
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai has huge resource for research. 
The facilities have the newest equipment.
 They are making a real effort to promote translational research.
cons:
The atmosphere for postdocs is competitive.
There is no real support system to encourage developing a career outside of academia for postdocs or it is discouraged by PI.
The  postdocs turn over is pretty high.

But anyhow, this is pretty common in biology research. It is not specific to Sinai but a broader problem with postdocs being consider as slaves because they are getting training to get their future lab so institutions are making them a favour to pay them $42,000...

review_title: Great Hospital, Great Doctors, Poor Nursing Culture
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros:
Great benefits, great pay. Education assistance is awesome here.
Working in the CTICU, I see a lot of rare cases and lives changed from world renowned surgeons.
cons: The saying "old nurses eat their young" is true here. I have been an ICU nurse for 5 years, and here almost 1 year. Man, have I never felt so put down by the staff on this unit. I know I'm a good nurse, the providers trust my judgement, my patient's always give me praise and thanks for great care, but sometimes when giving report to the oncoming nurse, you'd think I killed their dog! The attitudes of the older nurses on my unit are unbelievable. I have seen several people come and go for that reason and management is nice, but they're extremely unorganized.

job_title: Operations Manager in New York, NY
pros: Mount Sinai Health Partners, their population health group, is made up of competent, hard-working people, and led by a talented, humble leadership team. Though only some roles are "9-to-5", managers care about work-life sustainability. MSHP is one of the population health leaders in NYC, which is motivating. It's usually clear to staff how their contributions are part of the greater strategy. Office space in midtown is way above average for a non-profit health system role. If you want to work for a health system doing population health in NYC, this is the one you want to work for.
cons: MSHP is split between two locations, and some of our work has us going to other locations (e.g. our scattered hospitals) as well; resourcing constraints are not too bad, but definitely different from a for-profit setting; sometimes the slow pace in our healthcare context can be demotivating.

review_title: If Only Great Work Was Rewarded!
job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
